text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with homemade ice cream cones
that's right if only people knew how
easy it was to make ice cream cones at
home well they probably still buy them
at the store since generally people
prefer no effort over even a little
effort so we're not going to make our
own cones because they're easier or
cheaper or taste better which by the way
they do now we're going to make these
because years from now no one's going to
be sitting around reminiscing about the
time you went to the store to buy these
and besides if you make your own
homemade ice cream which uses yolks
you're going to have a few egg whites
sitting around waiting to be used and
that is exactly how we're going to start
this very simple batter so we'll start
with two preferably room-temperature egg
whites in a bowl to which we will add
some sugar and then we'll go ahead and
take a whisk and mix this for a couple
minutes or until the mixture is smooth
and sort of shiny and by the way I
should mention I'm using white sugar
here but if you're looking for something
a little closer to the traditional sugar
cone there are recipes that call for all
or part brown sugar in this but of
course that kind of thing is going to be
up to you you guys are after all the
rolling stones of your homemade cones so
if you think brown sugar will make these
tastes so good feel free to adjust but
either way we're going to mix our egg
whites and sugar together for a couple
minutes until it looks like this at
which point we'll stop and add the rest
of the ingredients which will include a
splash of whole milk as well as a little
touch of pure vanilla extract and I
believe that was exactly 15 small drops
also known as a quarter teaspoon and
then we're definitely going to need to
add some melted butter as well as a
little touch of cold fresh water and
then we'll finish this batter up by
tossing in some all-purpose flour and
then we'll grab a whisk and mix this
until completely smooth and if you're
thinking to yourself shouldn't there be
a pinch of salt in this yes there should
be which I forgot to add so I stopped
and tossed in a pinch and continued
mixing and then speaking of ingredients
no matter how much water and flour I
call for you may have to add some more
water or flour to adjust the thickness
of your batter which is kind of hard to
tell just by watching the whisking so
let me let this rest for a second while
I grab a ladle you give you a better
look at exactly where you're shooting
for
general err on the side of a little too
thick because if your batter is too thin
your cones are going to be too fragile
and they'll fall apart when you try to
top them with ice cream
all right so adjust if need be but we
want to get our batter at least this
thick and then once we're happy with our
batter we are ready to make icecream
cones as soon as we make our ice cream
cone cone or ice cream cone mold or form
or whatever word you want to use and
while you can buy these online or at the
store you shouldn't because not only is
it pretty easy to wad up some heavy-duty
aluminum foil into this sort of cone
shaped object but the irregularities in
the surface actually make this work
better and it releases easier from the
cooked cone so if you want to buy some
molds go ahead but this really does work
out beautifully and then once we have
our batter set and our ice cream cone
cone is done we are ready to move into
final assembly which means we're going
to ladle some of our batter onto a
Silpat lined baking sheet and we'll use
the bottom of the ladle to kind of
spread that out into as large a circle
as we want now because the pans cold
these first two are going to be the
hardest as you'll see when you're
working with a pan that's already warmed
up this batter will spread out a lot
easier but anyway we'll do two per pan
spreading that out as best we can with
the ladle and then if we need to do some
fine-tuning we could do that with a
spatula or I prefer this pastry brush
and again it's probably only the first
couple you're going to have to do this
with sure I guess we could have warmed
the pan up in the oven first but it's
too late now plus life's too short for
regrets so I simply smooth those out
with the brush at which point these are
ready for the oven just as soon as we
give them the old habit abba oh yeah
it's been a while so we will bang that a
few times on the countertop to settle it
down at which point we can transfer that
into the center of a 400 degree oven for
about eight minutes or so or until the
edges are nicely browned and they look
like this and then what we'll do as soon
as these come out as grab a spatula and
kind of go around making sure it's
loosened from the pan and one thing
that's going to be very obvious as
you're working with these they're only
shapeable while hot okay as soon as
these cool off which is very very
quickly they're going to turn hard and
crispy so we have to work fast here okay
so we'll loosen that with our spatula
and then roll that up as shown and as
you do this make sure you pinch the end
to seal the bottom
and other than that the only other tip
I'd say is try to end up with the seam
underneath and really that's it in just
a few seconds that's going to harden up
and we are going to be the proud owners
of one beautiful homemade ice cream cone
except once it's done do not leave it on
the hot pan while you take pictures
because that side will soften up and
flatten out and it will look like this
which still looks pretty cool but that
it's not perfectly round would bother
some people you know who you are and
then very important before we try to
shape the next one we need to pop this
back in the oven for about a minute
otherwise it's going to be very
difficult to roll okay this that really
doesn't need to be hot and soft before
you shape it which reminds me may want
to wear gloves for this is this is
fairly painful I mean it's worth it but
it's painful so just a little bit of a
heads up you might burn your fingertips
a little bit doing this but the good
news is next time it won't hurt as much
but anyway I continued on with the rest
of the batter which I'm going to say is
enough to make eight but I ended up with
enough batter to make this extra ninth
one and the reason I'm showing you this
one is because you might think these are
all easy and they roll perfectly but
they don't even if you've done this
hundreds of times okay first of all I
did a pretty bad job making sure was
loosened with the spatula so it sort of
got stuck so I had to grab a spatula
again to loosen it and then my cone cone
moved out of position so I had a
shoulder shove that back in and continue
on but the moral of the story despite
all those challenges the cone still came
out quite beautifully as long as they're
still hot and flexible you can always
reshape so like I said and as you can
see I ended up with nine but this amount
of batter will make anywhere between
eight and ten depending on the size and
at this point I might go ahead and grab
my ugliest one so we can do a little bit
of a taste and sound test sans ice cream
and even though it might look a little
thin they're delicate these things are
surprisingly crunchy and stirred and in
my humble opinion more delicious than
the store-bought
so I was very happy with how this came
out and by the way you should do this
test with your first one because if it
does end up being too fragile and too
delicate just go ahead and add some more
flour to your batter which will make
these thicker and more sturdy so again
it's going to be up to you to adjust and
I'll remind you of that tip on the blog
but in the meantime I'm going to proceed
to the most predictable ending and food
wishes video history I'm going to go
ahead and top this with some ice cream
and eat it and know I did make my own
chocolate ice cream for this I mean I
could have it just chose not to
but as maybe you saw in the last video
did pair quite nicely with our frozen
vanilla custard also known as french
vanilla ice cream but whether you're
going to enjoy this with homemade ice
cream or not I still really do hope you
give this a try soon so head over to
food wishes dot-com for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
[Music]
